conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for checking in again and for stating your commitment so clearly.

In general terms, the reason we are still holding the seat is not that we are waiting on a single specific decision from one person, but that one or more higher-priority students may still choose to apply to School_C in a later round depending on outcomes at their higher-ranked schools. As long as that remains plausible within the process, we need to keep the seat available.

What would change our position is if it becomes clear—based on how the remaining rounds unfold—that we are unlikely to receive an application from any higher-priority student. If that point is reached and our seat is still open, we would then reconsider remaining interested students immediately.

I realize that’s not a firm round-number guarantee, but it is the most accurate description of our current constraint. You’re welcome to check back again in upcoming rounds if you remain unmatched.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued patience and for asking in such a clear, practical way.

The most concrete signal we use is whether the students who are above you on our priority list appear to have effectively “exited” the possibility of applying to School_C—i.e., it becomes very likely they have secured seats at schools they prefer (or otherwise are no longer searching). In this process we don’t receive formal commitment notices, so we infer it from how the market evolves: if higher-priority students stop circulating and it becomes increasingly unlikely they would pivot to School_C as a fallback.

Practically, that means we would be ready to commit our seat to another interested student only when (a) no higher-priority student has applied to us, and (b) the remaining rounds are few enough / the market state stable enough that a late higher-priority application is no longer realistically expected.

As of round 11, we still consider at least one higher-priority student as plausibly able to apply here later depending on outcomes elsewhere, so we are not ready to commit the seat yet. If you remain unmatched, you’re welcome to check back again in upcoming rounds; we will re-evaluate immediately as soon as that risk meaningfully drops.

Sincerely,

On your question: in the last couple of rounds, we have not received new outreach or an application to School_C from any student who is above you on our priority list.

That said, we still need to keep our seat available for the possibility of a late application from a higher-priority student—most realistically someone for whom School_C is still a viable fallback depending on how their higher-ranked options resolve. Because we don’t receive formal “matched elsewhere” notices, we can only adjust once it becomes clear from the market that those higher-priority candidates are effectively no longer in play, or once we get close enough to the end of the process that a late pivot becomes very unlikely.

If you remain unmatched, please continue to check back; we will re-evaluate promptly as the remaining rounds narrow and the likelihood of a higher-priority late application drops.

Sincerely,

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued patience and for asking for a clearer condition.

Within the limits of this process (we don’t receive official “matched elsewhere” confirmations), the practical threshold we use is a combination of:

1) **No applications from any higher-priority student** (above you on our list) through the next several rounds, and
2) **Being close enough to the end of the process** that a late pivot from a higher-priority student is no longer realistically expected.

Concretely, if we reach approximately **round 20** with **no [APPLY] from any higher-priority student**, and School_C is still unfilled, we would plan to **stop holding the seat exclusively for hypothetical late applications** and would be prepared to move forward with an eligible remaining applicant at that time.

I understand that is still not immediate, but it is the most specific guidance we can give while we continue to preserve the seat for higher-priority candidates who may yet need a fallback.

If you remain unmatched, please check back with us around that point (or sooner if there is a major change in the market), and we will re-evaluate promptly.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

Thank you for checking in, and I appreciate how consistently and clearly you’ve expressed your interest in School_C.

To your first question: **no**, we have **not** received any new [APPLY] (or other serious outreach indicating an imminent [APPLY]) in rounds **13–14** from any student who is above you on our priority list.

On whether there is an *earlier* condition than ~round 20: **yes**—the main earlier condition would be if it becomes sufficiently clear from how the market is unfolding that the higher-priority students (above you on our list) are **stably placed elsewhere** and therefore a late pivot to School_C is no longer realistic. Because we don’t get formal “matched elsewhere” notifications, we can’t tie this to a single guaranteed signal, but if the market dynamics strongly indicate those candidates have effectively exited, we would be willing to move earlier than round 20.

As of round 14, we still view at least one higher-priority late application as plausible, so we are **not ready to commit the seat yet**. If you remain unmatched, please check in again over the next few rounds—if the situation clarifies materially, we will re-evaluate immediately.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
